responses.G15: A colonoscopy is performed by inserting a colonoscope, a long, flexible tube with a small camera on the end, into your rectum. The colonoscope is then gently guided through your colon. The camera on the colonoscope transmits images to a monitor, allowing your doctor to examine the lining of your colon. During the procedure, your doctor may take tissue samples, called biopsies, for further testing. After the procedure, you'll be monitored until most of the effects of the sedative have worn off. responses.G15DPO: A colonoscopy is performed by inserting a long, flexible tube called a colonoscope into your rectum. The colonoscope has a small camera at the end that allows your doctor to view the inside of your colon on a monitor. During the procedure, your doctor may take tissue samples, called biopsies, if they see anything unusual. These samples are then sent to a lab for further testing. After the procedure, you may feel bloated or have mild cramping because of the air introduced into the colon during the examination. This should disappear quickly when you pass gas.
